member.name: T:Sudoku.Buffers.FastProperties
member.summary: Provides and encapsulates the fast properties that is used in solving and analyzing a sudoku puzzle.

remarks.para: The whole class is a one, which means you can't use clause to create a new instance of this type. In contrast, the class is used for providing with properties used in a cyclic manually searching (i.e. in ).
Some step searchers rely on this type. If you want to call them separately, you should ensure the method in this type must be called before using these properties.

If a step searcher doesn't rely on this class, it'll be for the property named . If you find that the step searcher marks that attribute, you can call it everywhere safely; however, if the searcher isn't marked that attribute, you can't call it everywhere unless you call the method .

Please note, all names of properties in this class can also be found in , which means you can also call the property by . Of course, some of them doesn't contain the same one in , but you can find a same property whose execution logic (handling logic) is totally same. For example, is same as . The difference between them is that you shouldn't use until you have called , while can be used everywhere, because it isn't an instant property (which means the calculation begins when you called them, i.e. lazy ones; in contrast, some properties only store values directly, so their values can be got instantly, i.e. instant ones).

member.name: M:Sudoku.Filtering.TechniqueFiltering.KeywordPattern
member.remarks:
Pattern explanation:
○ 1st capture group.
○ Match with 2 alternative expressions, atomically.
○ Match a sequence of expressions.
○ Match a character in the set [Dd].
○ Match a character in the set [Ii].
○ Match a character in the set [Ff] exactly 2 times.
○ Match a character in the set [Ii].
○ Match a character in the set [Cc].
○ Match a character in the set [Uu].
○ Match a character in the set [Ll].
○ Match a character in the set [Tt].
○ Match a character in the set [Yy].
○ Match a sequence of expressions.
○ Match a character in the set [Nn].
○ Match a character in the set [Aa].
○ Match a character in the set [Mm].
○ Match a character in the set [Ee].

summary.para: Provides with the type that contains a module initializer method, called automatically by the CLR (Common Language Runtime) to initialize some values.

para.i: The type is called by the compiler and the CLR (Common Language Runtime), which means you cannot use any members in this type manually.

target.name: method
target.summary: Called by the runtime automatically while booting on this solution to initialize the values, data members or any other things that can or should be initialized here.
target.remarks: The concept module is different with assembly. The solution can contain multiple assemblies, while each assembly can contain multiple modules. However, due to the design of Visual Studio project file system, each assembly will only contain one module by default.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.LogicalSolverResult
member.summary: Provides the solver result after solving a puzzle.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.LogicalSolverResult.#ctor(Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@)
member.summary: Provides the solver result after solving a puzzle.

summary.para: Indicates the maximum difficulty of the puzzle.

When the puzzle is solved by , the value will be the maximum value among all difficulty ratings in solving steps. If the puzzle has not been solved, or else the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be always 20.0M.
Indicates the total difficulty rating of the puzzle.

When the puzzle is solved by , the value will be the sum of all difficulty ratings of steps. If the puzzle has not been solved, the value will be the sum of all difficulty ratings of steps recorded in . However, if the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be 0.
Indicates the pearl difficulty rating of the puzzle, calculated during only by .
When the puzzle is solved, the value will be the difficulty rating of the first solving step. If the puzzle has not solved or the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be always 0.
Indicates the pearl difficulty rating of the puzzle, calculated during only by .

When the puzzle is solved, the value will be the difficulty rating of the first step before the first one whose conclusion is . If the puzzle has not solved or solved by other solvers, this value will be 20.0M.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.LogicalSolverResult.Steps
member.summary: Indicates all solving steps that the solver has recorded.

summary.para: Indicates a list of pairs of information about each step.
If the puzzle cannot be solved due to some reason (invalid puzzle, unhandled exception, etc.), the return value of the property will be always the expression of type , of of types and .

Indicates the wrong step found. In general cases, if the property keeps value, it'll mean the puzzle is invalid to solve, or the solver has found one error step to apply, that causes the original puzzle become invalid. In this case we can check this property to get the wrong information to debug the error, or tell the author himself directly, with the inner value of this property held.
However, if the puzzle is successful to be solved, the property won't contain any value, so it'll keep the reference. Therefore, please check the nullability of this property before using.

In general, this table will tell us the nullability of this property:
Nullability Description
Not The puzzle is failed to solve, and the solver has found an invalid step to apply.
Other cases.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Patterns.AlternatingInferenceChain
member.summary:
Defines an alternating inference chain. The data structure can describe the following techniques:
Normal chains:
Irregular Wings
W-Wing
M-Wing
Split Wing
Local Wing
Hybrid Wing
Purple Cow
Discontinuous Nice Loop
Alternating Inference Chain
Continuous Nice Loop
Grouped chains (which means the nodes are not limited in sole candidates):
Grouped Wings
Grouped Discontinuous Nice Loop
Grouped Alternating Inference Chain
Grouped Continuous Nice Loop

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Patterns.AlternatingInferenceChain.#ctor(Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Patterns.Node[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes an instance via the specified nodes and the value indicating whether the chain starts and ends with strong inferences.
member.param: Indicates whether the chain starts and ends with strong inferences.
member.exception: Throws when the length of the argument is less than or equals 3, or the first and the last node aren't the same when the argument is .

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Patterns.AlternatingInferenceChain.IsStrong
member.summary: Indicates whether the alternating inference chain starts with a strong inference, and ends with another strong inference.

member.summary: Indicates whether the current chain is a grouped chain.

member.summary: Determines whether the current chain is an irregular wing (Chinese: Duan3 Lian4).

member.summary: Determines whether the chain only uses ALS grouped node as the strong inferences.

The value of the property Description
All nodes will be returned (i.e. _nodes[..]).

a. 25 | d. 28 b. 25 | e. 38 c. 3+ | f. 5+

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Patterns.ExocetPattern

summary.para:
Indicates an exocet pattern. The pattern will be like:
.-------.-------.-------. | B B E | E . . | E . . | | . . E | Q . . | R . . | | . . E | Q . . | R . . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . S | S . . | S . . | | . . S | S . . | S . . | | . . S | S . . | S . . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . S | S . . | S . . | | . . S | S . . | S . . | | . . S | S . . | S . . | '-------'-------'-------'
Where:
BBase Cells.
Q1st Object Pair (Target cells pair 1).
R2nd Object Pair (Target cells pair 2).
SCross-line Cells.
EEscape Cells.

In the data structure, all letters will be used as the same one in this exemplar. In addition, if senior exocet, one of two target cells will lie in cross-line cells, and the lines of two target cells lying on can't contain any base digits.

member.param: Indicates the first target cell in the Q part.
Indicates the second target cell in the Q part.
Indicates the first target cell in the R part.
Indicates the second target cell in the R part.
Indicates the first mirror cell in the Q part.
Indicates the second mirror cell in the Q part.
Indicates the first mirror cell in the R part.
Indicates the second mirror cell in the R part.

S | S . . | S . . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . S | S . . | S . . | | . . S | S . . | S . . | | . . S | S . . | S . . | '-------'-------'-------'
Where:
BBase Cells.
Q1st Object Pair (Target cells pair 1).
R2nd Object Pair (Target cells pair 2).

member.summary:
Defines a pattern that is a Qiu's deadly pattern technique structure in theory. The sketch is like:
.-------.-------.-------. | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | | P P . | . . . | . . . | :-------+-------+-------: | S S B | B B B | B B B | | S S B | B B B | B B B | | . . . | . . . | . . . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
Where:
PPair Cells.
SSquare Cells.
BBase-line Cells.
member.param: The square cells that is S in that sketch.
The base-line cells that is B in that sketch.
The pair cells that is P in that sketch.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Patterns.UniquePolygonPattern
member.summary:
Defines a pattern that is a unique polygon technique structure in theory. The sketch is like:
.-------.-------.-------. | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | P P . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . . | . . Q | S S . | | . . . | . . Q | S(S). | | . . . | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
Where:
PThe first group of cells.
QThe second group of cells.
S
The square cells of size 3 or 4. The cell with the bracket (r8c8 in the picture) is optional.
member.param: The mask that forms a structure.

remarks.para:
This is of type , where the distribution of each bit is as follows:
0 7 14 21 28 35 42 49 56 ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ |-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------| ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ 0 8 16 24 32 40 48 56 64
where the bit [0..56] is for 8 cells, the last 7 bits determine the pattern is a heptagon or a octagon. If the value is 127 (not available), the pattern will be a heptagon.
Due to the rendering engine, you have to check this file rather than the tip window.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.StepExtensions.IsChaining``1(``0)
member.summary:
Indicates whether the corresponding technique of the current step is a chain. The chain techniques are:
Wings
Regular wings (XY-Wing, XYZ-Wing, WXYZ-Wing, etc.)
Irregular wings (W-Wing, M-Wing, Split-Wing, Local-Wing, Hybrid-Wing)
Short chains
Two strong links (Skyscraper, Two-string kite, Turbot fish)
ALS chaining-like techniques
ALS-XZ
ALS-XY-Wing
ALS-W-Wing
Empty rectangle

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.StepExtensions.IsDeadlyPattern``1(``0)
member.summary:
Indicates whether the corresponding technique of the current step is a deadly pattern. The deadly pattern techniques are:
Bi-value patterns
Unique rectangle (i.e. Uniqueness test)
Unique loop
Bi-value universal grave
Multi-value patterns
Extended rectangle
Unique square
Unique polygon (Borescoper's deadly pattern as its alias)
Qiu's deadly pattern

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.StepSearchers.AlmostLockedCandidatesStepSearcher.GetAll(Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.LogicalAnalysisContext@,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@)
member.summary: Process the calculation.

remarks.para:
The diagrams:
ALP: abx aby | ab abz |
ALT: abcw abcx | abc abc abcy abcz |
Algorithm:

If the cell ab (in ALP) or abc (in ALT) is filled with the digit p, then the cells abx and aby (in ALP) and abcw and abcx (in ALT) can't fill the digit p. Therefore the digit p can only be filled into the left-side block.
If the block only contains those cells that can contain the digit p, the ALP or ALT will be formed, and the elimination is z (in ALP) and y and z (in ALT).
This algorithm uses a concept called Restricted Common Candidate (abbr. RCC) to limit the implementation. If you don't know that is an RCC, this link will tell you what is it.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.StepSearchers.AlternatingInferenceChainStepSearcher.MaxCapacity
member.remarks: The default value is 3000.

remarks.para:
This method use a very simple method to search for AICs. We should treat all AICs as "specialized" discontinuous nice loops. In this way we can get two kinds of chains:
Type 1:
A / \ B===C
(Strong link B == C, eliminate A)
Type 2:
A // \\ B---C
(Strong link A == B -- C == A, set A)
We should search for those two kinds of chains, and then encapsulates to a human-friendly view.

para.b: TODO: We should record the relations for the advanced nodes, in order to create a good look.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.StepSearchers.AlternatingInferenceChainStepSearcher.GatherInferences_LockedCandidates
member.summary: Gather the strong and weak inferences on locked candidates nodes.

remarks.para:
When we implement on this, we should consider 5 cases in total:
One digit lies in 2 blocks in a row.
One digit lies in 2 blocks in a column.
One digit lies in 2 rows in a block.
One digit lies in 2 columns in a block.
One digit lies in 1 row and 1 column in a block. We should treat it as a special case because the intersection cell may be used in both locked candidates nodes. We should consider on both cases.

Provides with an Alternating Inference Chain step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Non-grouped chains:
Irregular Wings:
W-Wing (Although it can be searched via )
M-Wing
Split Wing
Local Wing
Hybrid Wing
Purple Cow
Discontinuous Nice Loop
Alternating Inference Chain
Continuous Nice Loop
Grouped chains:
Grouped Irregular Wings
Grouped Discontinuous Nice Loop
Grouped Alternating Inference Chain
Grouped Continuous Nice Loop

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.StepSearchers.IAlternatingInferenceChainStepSearcher.MaxCapacity
member.summary: Indicates the maximum capacity used for the allocation on shared memory.

summary.para: Indicates the extended nodes to be searched for. Please note that the type of the property is an enumeration type with bit-fields attribute, which means you can add multiple choices into the value.

You can set the value as a bit-field mask to define your own types to be searched for, where:
Field name Description (What kind of nodes can be searched)
The strong and weak inferences between 2 sole candidate nodes of a same digit (i.e. X-Chain).
The strong and weak inferences between 2 sole candidate nodes of a same cell (i.e. Y-Chain).
The strong and weak inferences between 2 nodes, where at least one node is a locked candidates node.
The strong inferences between 2 nodes, where at least one node is an almost locked set node.
The weak inferences between 2 nodes, where at least one node is an almost hidden set node.
The strong and weak inferences between 2 nodes, where at least one node is an almost unique rectangle node.
The strong and weak inferences between 2 nodes, where at least one node is an XYZ-Wing node.
The strong and weak inferences between 2 nodes, where at least one node is a kraken fish node.
Other typed inferences are being considered, such as an XYZ-Wing node, etc.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.StepSearchers.IAlternatingInferenceChainStepSearcher.IsNodesRedundant(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Checks whether the node list is redundant, which means the list contains duplicate link node IDs in the non- endpoint nodes.

summary.para:
Provides with a Bi-value Oddagon step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Bi-value Oddagon Type 2
Bi-value Oddagon Type 3
In practicing, type 1 and 4 do not exist. A bi-value oddagon type 1 is a remote pair and a type 4 cannot be formed as a stable technique structure.
A remote pair is a XY-Chain that only uses two digits. This technique will be resolved by .

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.StepSearchers.IBivalueUniversalGraveStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with a Bi-value Universal Grave step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Basic types:

Bi-value Universal Grave Type 2

Bi-value Universal Grave Type 4
Extended types:

Bi-value Universal Grave False Candidate Type

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.StepSearchers.IBivalueUniversalGraveStepSearcher.SearchExtendedTypes
member.summary: Indicates whether the searcher should call the extended BUG checker to search for all true candidates no matter how difficult searching.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.StepSearchers.IBivalueUniversalGraveStepSearcher.FindTrueCandidates(Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@,System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyList{System.Int32}@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Finds all possible true candidates in this current grid.
member.param: The grid to find all possible true candidates.
Indicates the maximum number of possible cells to check.
member.returns: A value indicating whether the grid contains any possible true candidates. If so, the argument won't be .
member.remarks: A true candidate is a candidate that makes the puzzle containing no valid solution if it is eliminated from the current puzzle. It is a strict concept, which means sometimes the puzzle doesn't contain any satisfied candidate to make the puzzle containing no solution if being eliminated.
member.exception: Throws when the puzzle contains multiple solutions or even no solution.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.StepSearchers.IUniqueRectangleStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with a Unique Rectangle step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Basic types:
Unique Rectangle Type 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
Avoidable Rectangle Type 1, 2, 3, 5
Hidden Unique Rectangle
Hidden Avoidable Rectangle
Structured types:
Unique Rectangle + Conjugate Pair (also called "Unique Rectangle + Strong Link")
Avoidable Rectangle + Hidden Single
Unique Rectangle + Unknown Covering
Unique Rectangle + Sue de Coq
Unique Rectangle + Guardian (This program call it "Unique Rectangle External Types"):
Unique Rectangle External Type 1
Unique Rectangle External Type 2
Unique Rectangle External Type 3
Unique Rectangle External Type 4
Unique Rectangle External Type with XY-Wing
Unique Rectangle External Type with ALS-XZ
Avoidable Rectangle + Guardian (Sub-types are same like above)
Miscellaneous types:
Unique Rectangle 2D
Unique Rectangle 3X

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.StepSearchers.IUniqueRectangleStepSearcher.AllowIncompleteUniqueRectangles
member.summary: Indicates whether the UR can be incomplete. In other words, some of UR candidates can be removed before the pattern forms.
member.remarks:
For example, the complete pattern is:
ab | ab ab | ab
This is a complete pattern, and we may remove an ab in a certain corner. The incomplete pattern may not contain all four abs in the structure.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.StepSearchers.IUniqueRectangleStepSearcher.SearchForExtendedUniqueRectangles
member.summary: Indicates whether the searcher can search for extended URs.
member.remarks: The basic types are type 1 to type 6, all other types are extended ones.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.StepSearchers.JuniorExocetStepSearcher.CheckCrossLineCells(Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Patterns.ExocetPattern@,System.Int16)
member.summary: Checks for the validity of the cross-line cells, guaranteeing the target cells is valid in the full exocet map.

remarks.para: The main idea of this searching operation:

.-------.-------.-------. | C C C | A A A | A A A | | B B B | . . . | . . . | | B B B | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
For example, if the cells C form a locked candidates, there'll be two cases:
Pointing (Type 1): Cells A contains the digit, but cells B doesn't.
Claiming (Type 2): Cells B contains the digit, but cells A doesn't.

Therefore, the algorithm is: Use bitwise-or operator | to gather all candidate masks from cells A, cells B and cells C, and suppose the notation a is the mask result for cells A, b is the mask result for cells B, and c is the mask result for cells C. If the equation (c & (a ^ b)) != 0 is correct, the locked candidates exists, and the result of the expression c & (a ^ b) is a mask that holds the digits of the locked candidates.

Why this expression? a ^ b means the digit can only appear in either cells A or cells B. If both or neither, the digit won't contain the locked candidates structure. Because of the optimization of the performance, we use the predefined table to iterate on all possible location where may form a locked candidate.

member.summary: Checks for type 2. In this type we also check the generalized case that looks like a UR type 5.

remarks.para: This implementation is based on the theory mentioned from RW:
If a group of all instances of N different digits in a chute is spread over max N+1 mini- rows/columns, then the group will contain at least one unavoidable set.
This technique too complex to be proved, but I find this link to describe about this technique:

member.summary: Check whether the highlight UR candidates is incomplete.
member.remarks: This method uses a trick to check a UR structure: to count up the number of "Normal colored" candidates used in the current UR structure. If and only if the full structure uses 8 candidates colored with normal one, the structure will be complete.

member.summary: Check type 1.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ cornerCell (abc) ab ab ab

member.summary: Check type 2.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ corner1, corner2 (abc) (abc) ab ab

member.summary: Check type 3.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ corner1, corner2 (ab ) (ab ) abx aby

member.summary: Check type 4.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ corner1, corner2 (ab ) ab abx aby

member.summary: Check type 5.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ cornerCell (ab ) abc abc abc

member.summary: Check type 6.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ corner1 (ab ) aby abx (ab) ↑corner2

member.summary: Check hidden UR.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ cornerCell (ab ) abx aby abz

member.summary: Check UR + 2D.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ corner1 (ab ) abx aby (ab ) xy * ↑ corner2

member.summary: Check UR + 2B/1SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ corner1, corner2 (ab ) (ab ) | | a | abx aby

member.summary: Check UR + 2D/1SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ corner1 (ab ) aby | | a | abx (ab ) ↑ corner2

member.summary: Check UR + 3X.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ cornerCell (ab ) abx aby abz xy *
Note: z is x or y.

member.summary: Check UR + 3X/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ cornerCell (ab ) abx | | b a | aby-----abz

member.summary: Check UR + 3N/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ cornerCell (ab )-----abx a | | b | aby abz

member.summary: Check UR + 3U/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ cornerCell (ab )-----abx a
b aby -----abz

member.summary: Check UR + 3E/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ cornerCell (ab )-----abx a
a aby -----abz

member.summary: Check UR + 4X/3SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
↓ corner1, corner2 (abx)-----(aby) a | | b a | abz ----- abw

member.summary: Check UR + 4C/3SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.

remarks.para: The structures:

Subtype 1:
↓ corner1, corner2 (abx)-----(aby) a | | a b | abz ----- abw

Subtype 2:
↓ corner1, corner2 (abx)-----(aby) | a | | b | a | | abz abw

member.summary: Check UR-XY-Wing, UR-XYZ-Wing, UR-WXYZ-Wing and AR-XY-Wing, AR-XYZ-Wing and AR-WXYZ-Wing.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
The size of the wing to search.

remarks.para: The structures:

Subtype 1:
↓ corner1 (ab ) abxy yz xz (ab ) abxy * ↑ corner2
Note that the pair of cells abxy should be in the same house.

Subtype 2:
↓ corner1 (ab ) abx xz aby (ab ) * yz ↑ corner2

member.summary: Check UR + SdC.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The structure:
| xyz ab+ ab+ | abxyz abxyz | xyz ----------+------------ (ab)(ab) | ↑ corner1, corner2

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.StepSearchers.UniqueRectangleStepSearcher.CheckUnknownCoveringUnique(System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Steps.UniqueRectangleStep},Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@,System.Int32[],System.Int16,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Check UR + Unknown covering.

remarks.para: The structures:

Subtype 1:
↓urCellInSameBlock ab abc abc ←anotherCell
abcx-----abcy ←resultCell c ↑targetCell
Where the digit a and b in the bottom-left cell abcx can be removed.

Subtype 2:
abcx | ab abc | | | c | | | abcy | abc

member.summary: Indicates whether the specified chain is an XY-Chain.

member.summary: Indicates whether the specified chain is an X-Chain.

member.summary: Indicates whether the specified chain is a remote pair.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Steps.AlternatingInferenceChainStep.IsWWing
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is W-Wing ((x = y) - y = y - (y = x)).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Steps.AlternatingInferenceChainStep.IsMWing
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is M-Wing ((x = y) - y = (y - x) = x).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Steps.AlternatingInferenceChainStep.IsSplitWing
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is Split-Wing (x = x - (x = y) - y = y).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Steps.AlternatingInferenceChainStep.IsHybridWing
member.summary:
Indicates whether the chain is Hybrid-Wing. This wing has two types:
(x = y) - y = (y - z) = z
(x = y) - (y = z) - z = z

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Steps.AlternatingInferenceChainStep.IsLocalWing
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is Local-Wing (x = (x - z) = (z - y) = y).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Steps.FishStep.Size
member.remarks:
The name of the corresponding names are:
2X-Wing
3Swordfish
4Jellyfish
5Squirmbag (or Starfish)
6Whale
7Leviathan
Other fishes of sizes not appearing in above don't have well-known names.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Steps.Specialized.IElementaryStep
member.summary: Defines a step whose technique used is the elementary one.
member.remarks:
Here we define that the techniques often appearing and commonly to be used as below are elementary:
Full House, Last Digit, Hidden Single, Naked Single
Pointing, Claiming
Naked Pair, Naked Triple, Naked Quadruple
Naked Pair (+), Naked Triple (+), Naked Quadruple (+)
Hidden Pair, Hidden Triple, Hidden Quadruple
Locked Pair, Locked Triple

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Steps.Specialized.IInvalidStep

member.name: F:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Steps.Specialized.IInvalidStep.Instance
member.summary: Indicates the only instance of type that can be used.
member.remarks: This instance is special. The instance will be used only if the step searcher found the puzzle being invalid to be successfully and correctly handled. All members existed in type are implemented with throwing behavior. In other words, you cannot use any possible members in this instance; otherwise you will get a instance.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Steps.Specialized.ILoopLikeStep.IsNice

summary.para: Indicates whether the current technique is the nice loop.
A Nice loop is a loop that all weak links can be gathered to remove candidates (if possible removable candidates exist).

member.returns:
The return value will be a ?:
The technique is the nice loop.
The technique is not a nice loop, e.g. a normal dynamic loop.
The technique is not a loop, but the structure forms a valid loop-shaped one, e.g. guardian.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Steps.Specialized.IStepWithRank
member.summary: Defines a step whose technique used is related to the rank theory, which contains the property Rank.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Steps.Specialized.IStepWithRank.Rank
member.summary: Indicates the rank of the technique structure.
member.returns:
The return value can be separated with the following cases:
Range Description
> 1
The technique cannot be applied any eliminations except the intersection that all possible branches can see.
1
The technique can be applied eliminations that is like a normal AIC.
0
The technique can be applied eliminations that is like a nice loop. For example, a Sue de Coq.
<= 1
The negative rank value cannot be formed because the technique structure is at an invalid status.
member.remarks: Please note that sometimes a complex structure may not contain a valid and stable rank value. You can visit this link for more details about the mixed-rank structures.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.Steps.UniqueRectangleStep
member.summary: Provides with a step that is a Unique Rectangle technique.

param.name: TechniqueCode2
param.para: Indicates the technique code.

Limited by the C# language, here we creates a new property to pass the value and assign it to the property . If write code to place the property into the primary constructor as a parameter, the default member named TechniqueCode may be duplicate with this parameter's, which isn't allowed in types in the language design.

member.param: Indicates the first digit used in this unique rectangle pattern.
Indicates the second digit used in this unique rectangle pattern.

param.name: IsAvoidable
param.para: Indicates whether the current unique rectangle is avoidable rectangle.
For the designation and the implementation, Avoidable Rectangle and Unique Rectangle are used as the same type.

param.name: AbsoluteOffset
param.para: Indicates the absolute offset.

The value will be an value to compare all possible cases of unique rectangle structures to be iterated. The greater the value is, the later the unique rectangle structure will be processed. The value must be between 0 and 485. Other values are invalid and useless. The number of all possible unique rectangle structures is 486.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.IStep
member.summary: Provides a basic logical solving step.

summary.para: Indicates whether the difficulty rating of this technique should be shown in the output screen. Some techniques such as Gurth's symmetrical placement doesn't need to show the difficulty (because the difficulty of this technique is unstable).
If the value is , the analysis result won't show the difficulty of this instance.
The default value is .

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.IStep.Name
member.summary: Indicates the technique name. The technique name are all stored in the resource dictionary, you can find them in the Resources folder (Type ).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.IStep.Format
member.summary: Gets the format of the current instance.
member.returns: Returns a result. If the resource dictionary doesn't contain any valid formats here, the result value will be .

remarks.para: A format is the better way to format the result text of this technique information instance. It'll be represented by the normal characters and the placeholders, e.g. "{Name}: Cells {CellsStr} => {ElimsStr}" Here the string result shouldn't be with the leading '$' character, because this is a format string instead of an interpolated one.

Here the property Name, CellsStr and ElimsStr must have been implemented before the property invoked. You should create 3 properties whose names are Name, CellsStr and ElimsStr, and return the corresponding correct string result, making them non- (suggested keyword is ) and applying attribute to it.

Because this property will get the value from the resource dictionary, the property supports multiple language switching, which is better than the normal methods ToString and ToFullString. Therefore, this property is the substitution of those two methods.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.IStep.Difficulty
member.summary: The difficulty or this step.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.IStep.TechniqueCode
member.summary: The technique code of this instance used for comparison (e.g. search for specified puzzle that contains this technique).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.IStep.TechniqueTags
member.summary: The technique tags of this instance.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.IStep.TechniqueGroup
member.summary: The technique group that this technique instance belongs to.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.IStep.DifficultyLevel
member.summary: The difficulty level of this step.
member.remarks: Although the type of this property is marked , we still can't set multiple flag values into the result. The flags are filtered during generating puzzles.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.IStep.Stableness
member.summary: Indicates the stableness of this technique. The default value is .

member.remarks: Although the type of this property is marked , we still can't set multiple flag values into the result. The flags are filtered during generating puzzles.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.IStep.ToSimpleString
member.summary: Returns a string that only contains the name and the conclusions.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.IStep.ToFullString
member.summary: Returns a string that contains the name, the conclusions and its all details. This method is used for displaying details in text box control.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.IStep.Formatize(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Formatizes the property string and output the result.
member.param: Indicates whether the method will handle the escaping characters.
member.exception:
Throws when the format is invalid. The possible cases are:
The format is .
The interpolation part contains the empty value.
Missing the closed brace character '}'.
The number of interpolations failed to match.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Logical.IStep.ElimStr
member.summary: Indicates the string representation of the conclusions.
member.remarks: Most of techniques uses eliminations so this property is named ElimStr. In other words, if the conclusion is an assignment one, the property will still use this name rather than AssignmentStr.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.CommonReadOnlies.BruteForceTryAndErrorOrder
member.summary: The order of cell offsets to get values.
member.remarks: For example, the first value is 40, which means the first cell to be tried to be filled is the 40th cell in the grid (i.e. the cell r5c5).

summary.para:
Indicates all maps that forms the each intersection. The pattern will be like:
.-------.-------.-------. | C C C | A A A | A A A | | B B B | . . . | . . . | | B B B | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
In addition, in this data structure, a CoverSet is a block and a BaseSet is a line.
The table of all blocks to iterate for each blocks.
This field is only used for providing the data for another field .
Indicates the constructor of the current type.
This constructor will initialize some data members of this type that can't use a simple expression to describe the initial value.

member.summary: Indicates whether the solver only find one possible step and exit the searcher.

para.para: The accumulator to store each step.

summary.para: If is set to , this argument will become useless because we only finding one step is okay, so we may not use the accumulator to store all possible steps, in order to optimize the performance. Therefore, this argument can be in this case.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherDisplayingLevel
member.summary: Indicates the difficulty level of the step. This enumeration type is used for the displaying of the step information list.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherDisplayingLevel.None
member.summary: Indicates the level is none.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherDisplayingLevel.A
member.summary: Indicates the level is the elementary searchers, which means the techniques found in the current step searcher is the elementary ones.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherDisplayingLevel.B
member.summary: Indicates the level is the moderate searchers, which means the techniques found in the current step searcher is more difficult than the elementary ones, but they aren't very difficult to comprehend the backing logic.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherDisplayingLevel.C
member.summary: Indicates the level is the hard searchers, which means the techniques found in the current step searcher is more difficult than the moderate ones.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherDisplayingLevel.D
member.summary: Indicates the level is the fiendish searchers, which means the techniques found in the current step searcher is more difficult than the hard ones.

summary.para: Indicates the level is the hidden searchers, which means the techniques found in the current step searcher should be hidden no matter how easy the technique is.
The well-known technique searcher of this level is Brute Force.

member.summary: Defines a reason why the puzzle is failed to be solved.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherFailedReason.Nothing
member.summary: Indicates nothing goes wrong.

summary.para: Indicates the failed reason is that the puzzle doesn't contain a valid unique solution.
Different with and , this field will include more generic cases. If the puzzle doesn't pass the pre-process operation before solving, we should use this field.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherFailedReason.PuzzleHasNoSolution
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the puzzle doesn't contain a valid solution.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherFailedReason.PuzzleHasMultipleSolutions
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the puzzle contains multiple valid solutions.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherFailedReason.UserCancelled
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the user has canceled the task.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherFailedReason.NotImplemented
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the solver or some searching module isn't implemented.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherFailedReason.ExceptionThrown
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the solver has encountered an error and couldn't solve that will cause an exception thrown.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherFailedReason.WrongStep
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the solver has found a wrong step that cause the grid become invalid.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherFailedReason.PuzzleIsTooHard
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the puzzle is too hard to solve. The solver gave up.

remarks.i: This option becomes deprecated at present because we has already implemented a step searcher that always produces a valid step, guaranteeing that the solver will never give up at all time.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Runtime.AnalysisServices.SearcherInitializationOptions
member.summary: Indicates the options for a step searcher used while searching.
member.param: Indicates the priority of this technique.
Indicates which areas the step searcher is enabled and works well. The default value is both and .

param.name: DisplayingLevel
param.para: Indicates the displaying level of this technique.
The display level means the which level the technique is at. All higher leveled techniques won't display on the screen when the searchers at the current level have found technique instances.

In order to enhance the performance, this attribute is used on a step gatherer. For example, if Alternating Inference Chain (AIC) is at the level but Forcing Chains (FC) is at the level , when we find any AIC technique instances, FC won't be checked at the same time.
This attribute is also used for grouping those the searchers, especially in Sudoku Explainer mode.

param.name: DisabledReason
param.para: Indicates whether the current searcher has bug to fix, or something else to describe why the searcher is (or should be) disabled.
The property must contain a value that differs with when the property isn't .
